refnamediv.refpurpose: Provide access to some methods in the CRingBuffer C++ API.

refsynopsisdiv.synopsis:
from nscldaq.ringbuffer import ringmaster
obj = ringmaster.ringmaster(hostname) adict = obj.usage() adict = obj.clients(ringname)

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class provides Python access to the query methods of the CRingMaster class. By using this class, python scripts can know the usage and statistics of all rings in the system as well as the command lines for the clients of the ring.

listitem.para: Constructs ringmaster object that is connected to the ring master server in hostname. Once constructed information can be retrieved from that ring master.
Returns a dictionary that describes the rings and usage of those rings in the host on which the object was constructed.
The result is a dict whose keys are the names of the ringbuffers that are defined in this node. Note that proxy rings will be included in the keys.
Each key contais a dict with the following key/values:
Number of byte of data the ringbuffer can hold.

The number of free bytes in the ring buffer. This is the ringbuffer distance between the put pointer and least caught up get pointer. If one attempts to insert more than this number of bytes the inserting program will block until space becomes available.

The maximum number of consumers that can simlutaneously attach to this ringbuffer. A ringbuffer consists of a header and data section. The header is fixed size and contains an array of structures for each consumer. This value is the size of that array.

The process Id of the producer for the ring. Each ringbuffer can have at most one producer. The producer is the program that places data into the ringbuffer. If there is not a current producer process, the value of this key is -1.
This is the largest amount of data available in the ring buffer over all consumers. It is distance between the furthest behind get pointer and the put pointer.
This is the minimum amount of data available in the ring buffer over all consumers. It is the distance between the most cauth up get pointer and the put pointer.
The number of put operations performed by the producer. This only has meaning if there is a current producer. This value is cleared when a producer attaches to the ring.
Since each ringitem is placed in the ringbuffer with a single put, this value describes the number of ring items that have been put in the buffer.
The number of bytes put into the ring buffer by the consumer. This only has meaning if there is a current producer. This value is cleared when a producer attaches to the ring.
This key contains a tuple that has one element for each consumer currently attached to the ring. Each tuple element is a dictionary with the following keys:
The process Id of the consumer.
The number of bytes that could be gotten by this consumer if it drained the ringbuffer now.

The number of get operations done by the consumer. Since each ring item is pulled from the ring with a single get operation, this value is the number of ring items the consumer has removed from the ring.
The number of bytes of data the consumer has pulled from the ringbuffer.
This method returns information about the commands running each client attached to the ring ringname. The result is a dict with two keys; prodcuer and consumers.

The producers key contains a tuple whose elements are the command words for the command that is attached to the ring as a producer. If no producer is currently attached, this tuple is empty. For example, if the producer is: ./Readout --ring=fox --source-id=6, the tuple will be ('./Readout', '--ring=fox', '--sourceid=6').

The consumers key is a possibly empty tuple. Each tuple itself contains a tuple that contains the words of the command which is attached to the ringbuffer as a consumer. Suppose, for example, the ring has two consumers, ringselector --sample=PHYSICS_EVENT --non-blocking fox, and ringtostdout fox spdaq20.nscl.msu.edu, The consumers key will have:
(('ringselector', '--sample=PHYSICS_EVENT', '--non-blocking', 'fox'), ('ringtostdout', 'fox', 'spdaq20.nscl.msu.edu'))

refnamediv.refpurpose: Get information about the systems that are getting/putting data to a host.

refsynopsisdiv.synopsis:
from nsldaq.ringbuffer import ringmaster
obj = ringmaster.connectivity(host) atuple = obj.producers() atuple = obj.consumers() atuple = obj.allParticipants()

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class provides methods that allow python scripts to learn which hosts are consumer data from or producing data into ringbuffers in a specific host.

listitem.para: Constructs a connectivity object that gets information from the ring master in the specified host.
Retrieves a (possibly empty) tuple that contains the fully qualified host names for hosts that are providing data to proxy rings in the host on which the object was constructed.

Returns a (possibly empty) tuple that contains a list of hosts that are receiving data from ringbuffers in the host on which this object was constructed. This is done by looking at the consumers in each ring, finding those that are of the form ringtostdout ringname hostname and extracting the hostname from the command.

Returns a tuple containing all the hosts participating in the data flow on which the connectivity object was constructed. Note that the tuple will have at least one element, the fully qualified canonical hostname of the host on which the object was constructed.
